Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Policing Citizenship in the United States: Violence and Differential Access to Public Space

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project examines how gender dynamics guide the state's public response to violence that occurs within the private space of the home. The spatial distinction of public and private space is critical to the conceptualization of intimate partner violence as well as to policing practices as a matter of public security and citizen protections. The project's objective is to study the connections between public space and citizenship, the state and its role in addressing the security needs of its citizens as well as the experiences of victims in this process. Three key questions guide this research: 1) How do gendered dynamics affect policing strategies regarding intimate partner violence? 2) How does the gendering of this policing affect the experience and practice of citizenship in relation to public space and security? 3) How does the gendering of policing strategies affect women's experience as citizens in particular places and times? While critical scholarship on terrorism and violence have recently been addressing the spatiality of policing, absent from this literature is an understanding of the gendered dimensions of policing at a more local scale. With a specific focus on the policing of intimate partner violence, this research will address this gap by providing new insights into the gendered and spatial dynamics of policing strategies that affect women's access to public space and citizenship rights. Further, this project will contribute to scholarly debates on policing and governance, private space and policing, and policing and exclusion. Lastly, this research advances understandings of how political processes affect women's position as citizens within the state by examining the current relationship between the state and victims, policing practices within the US and the impact of these processes on the lived experiences of victims. This research will be conducted via a qualitative study in central Pennsylvania.

In addition to academic dissemination via geographic and feminist-based scholarly journals, results from this research will be disseminated in formats accessible to non-academic communities as they address socially-relevant community policing strategies. Project results will be presented in public symposia and results will be made available in reports to local and state community organizations as well as the National Coalition Against Domestic Violence in such a way that they will be able to make on an impact on policy-making and policing practice regarding intimate partner violence. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this project will provide support to enable a promising student to establish an independent research career while providing timely research to address the issue of intimate partner violence.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the policing and prosecution response to intimate partner violence in a central Pennsylvania community to understand how gender assumptions guide the state’s public response to violence that occurs within the private space of the home.

Intimate partner violence is a gendered crime whose victims are overwhelmingly women. Throughout the United States, many police departments and district attorney’s offices employ the distinct policing strategies of preferred arrest and victim-less prosecution to address intimate partner violence. If a law enforcement officer comes into contact with someone who appears to have been physically assaulted by their intimate partner, based on physical corroborating evidence, the officer is required by law to arrest the perpetrator of violence. The arrest occurs regardless of victim consent. Likewise, victim-less prosecution allows prosecutors to move forward with a criminal case regardless of victim cooperation. These unique policing strategies, for a particularly gendered crime, point to an active gendering of the policing process. The researcher sought to understand how the policing response to intimate partner violence affects the practice of citizenship for women who experience such violence.

Over the course of two years of ethnographic fieldwork, the researcher conducted eighty interviews with judges, district attorneys, chiefs of police, law enforcement officers, probation and parole officers, prison staff, 911 dispatch operators, mental health professionals, victim advocates and survivors of intimate partner violence. The researcher observed the daily law enforcement response to intimate partner violence from within the domestic violence unit of a local police department and read hundreds of domestic violence police reports and Protection from Abuse Order petitions. The researcher also spent hundreds of hours observing criminal and civil court proceedings at the local courthouse, documenting the language district attorneys and judges used to shape their arguments and make rulings in domestic violence cases.

Following data analysis, findings indicate that policing strategies for intimate partner violence often limit individual autonomy for women who experience intimate partner violence. With practices couched in discursive language regarding protecting victims, this research indicates that the state response to this crime often works to reproduce battered women as helpless victims. Findings from this research also indicated that well-intentioned policing practices that result in the arrest and incarceration of perpetrators of intimate partner violence can paradoxically cause increased physical, financial and emotional insecurity for women who experience such violence. This research draws attention to the limitations of policing practices that focus exclusively on the criminal justice system as the means to addressing the problem of intimate partner violence without taking account of survivors multiple and varying physical, financial and emotional security needs.

Publications that result from this research project will yield significant knowledge to geographic understandings of the spatiality of policing. To date, there is no research in geography that investigates the spatial and gendered dimensions of policing in relation to intimate partner violence. This project will contribute to theory addressing how the spatiality of policing, particularly across the public-private divide, affects the gendered body. With its focus on the gendered dynamics of policing strategies for intimate partner violence, this project will provide new knowledge concerning how policing practices affect women's access to public space and citizenship rights.
